title: 106_hr1966
content: The Act may be cited as the "Asthma Awareness, Education and Treatment Act of 1999". The Congress finds that asthma affects 14.6 million Americans, including 4.8 million children, and is the most common chronic respiratory disease in children. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly, especially among low-income families. The prevalence of asthma is higher in low-income families, with 79.2 out of 1,000 individuals under 45 in families earning less than $10,000 annually having asthma. In 1997, over 5,000 Americans died from asthma attacks, with African Americans having a higher average death rate than Caucasians. Asthma costs the US over $12 billion annually, and African Americans are more likely to seek emergency care for asthma. The asthma death rate is significantly higher among African American children and adults. African Americans are five times more likely to seek emergency care for asthma. The asthma death rate is four times higher among African American children and two times higher among all African Americans. Exercise can help children manage asthma and improve their quality of life. Grants for asthma-related activities for low-income communities. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may provide grants to public and nonprofit entities for projects in low-income communities, including screenings, education, and workshops on asthma, allergies, and respiratory issues. Screenings and referrals must be comprehensive and provided in various settings like hospitals and health clinics. The Secretary ensures comprehensive screenings and referrals for asthma, allergies, and respiratory issues in various settings including medical facilities and nontraditional locations like schools, community centers, and government offices. Information and education are provided in appropriate language and cultural context. The information and education on asthma, allergies, and related respiratory problems include details on symptoms, prevention, monitoring, and management. It emphasizes the importance of understanding asthma triggers, appropriate medication options, and regular physical activity for asthmatic children. The evaluation of projects under subsection (a) includes determining the number of children screened and referred, assessing the impact on asthma prevention and management, and evaluating the effectiveness of materials used. The information and education provided cover symptoms, prevention, monitoring, and management of asthma, allergies, and related respiratory problems, emphasizing understanding triggers, medication options, and physical activity for asthmatic children in various settings. The evaluation of projects includes assessing screenings, referrals, and their impact on asthma prevention and management. Grants require involvement of local community-based organizations. Applications must be submitted to the Secretary in the specified form and manner. The Secretary may make a grant under subsection (a) only if an application is submitted in the specified form and manner, containing necessary agreements, assurances, and information. $8,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2000, with additional appropriations for fiscal years 2001 through 2004. SEC. 4. National media campaign for asthma-related information. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may award contracts for a national media campaign providing information on asthma, allergies, and respiratory problems, prioritizing children. The campaign must include prevention and management information, as well as details on community programs and language/cultural context. The campaign aims to provide information on asthma, allergies, and respiratory problems, focusing on children. It includes details on community programs, screenings, referrals, and treatment in appropriate language and cultural context. $600,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2000, with additional funding for subsequent years. Tax credit for donations of pest control and climate control services under SEC. 45D of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Tax credit for donations of pest control and climate control services is available for taxpayers providing qualified services without charge in public housing or multifamily residential rental properties with low-income occupants. The credit is 10 percent of the costs incurred in providing these services. The tax credit for donations of pest control and climate control services applies to multifamily residential rental properties with low-income occupants. The services must be part of a good faith effort to eliminate pests and improve climate control. The tax code is amended to include a donation credit for pest control and climate control services provided by taxpayers in the trade or business of offering these services. Unused credits cannot be carried back before January 1, 2000. The tax code now includes a credit for pest control and climate control services provided by businesses. Unused credits cannot be carried back before January 1, 2000. The tax code now includes a credit for donations of pest control and climate control services. The amendments made by this section will apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1999. Additionally, there is research being conducted on the relationship between air pollutants and asthma-related problems. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with the EPA Administrator, will conduct research to determine the link between air pollutants and asthma, allergies, and respiratory issues. Priority will be given to clinical evaluations for individuals in low-income communities. The research focuses on individuals in low-income communities with family incomes at or below 200 percent of the poverty line. SEC. 7. COORDINATION OF FEDERAL ACTIVITIES TO ADDRESS ASTHMA-RELATED HEALTH CARE NEEDS. The Director of the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute will identify federal programs for asthma, develop a federal response plan, and submit recommendations to Congress for better coordination. A representative from the Department of Housing and Urban Development will also be included in the coordinating committee. $5,000,000 will be allocated to the National Asthma Education Prevention Program. Development shall be included on the National Asthma Education Prevention Program Coordinating Committee to perform tasks described in subsection (a). $5,000,000 from the National Institutes of Health will be allocated to the Program for fiscal years 2000 through 2004 to carry out this section. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, in consultation with the National Asthma Education Prevention Program Coordinating Committee, will conduct local asthma surveillance activities to collect data on asthma prevalence, severity, and management. This includes telephone surveys and health care facility surveillance. They will compile and publish data on the prevalence of children with asthma in each state and childhood mortality rates associated with asthma nationally and by state.
